topic.title: Discussion: Sample Midterm exam
topic.msg:
Post questions about "Sample Midterm". Use the first line of your post as the subject of the post.

Sample midterm questions download download

entry.title: professional pigeon
entry.msg: how many possible methods are there to solve these questions?

entry.title: statutory squirrel
entry.msg: Well, in programming questions can be solved in many ways. I'd just say that you should go with a method which uses things discussed in class and not try to make it too complex (For example: its better to solve a problem in 10 lines of code that in 100).

entry.title: spatial snipe
entry.msg:
Like math, programming can be solved in different ways.  For instance, sorting has different techniques like O(n^2) algorithms - bubble, selection sort et al, or O(nlogn) algorithms like quick, heap sort, and O(1) algorithms like counting sort.  Anything that can be implemented in an optimized a way depending on the problem to be solved, we can approach the problem's solution in different ways.

Again, your question was pretty high level, so not sure my answer helped.

entry.title: supposed swordtail
entry.msg: If you try it, you can reverse it into that single byte. It's possible since the variable is at the end of the stack, so you won't end up writing into another variable's memory segment. Since the variables' combined sizes are far under the minimum stack size, there is enough room.

entry.title: dizzy cuckoo
entry.msg:
Help on understanding this:

#4 problem #4 question: 

  1. var1  SBYTE -4, -2, 3, 1

movsx edx, var1

Answer is: movsx edx,var1      ;  since -4 =fch then edx = fffffffch.

Can someone help to explain this? Thanks in advance!

entry.title: entitled earwig
entry.msg: Since, -4 = fch = 11111010 which is only 3 hex digits, but edx is 8, and since it's negative and uses movsx, it fills the entire gap with extra 1's (the sign bit) so it ends up looking like fffffffch

entry.title: faithful firefly
entry.msg:
Actually, -4 is fc h (space added for clarity that h is not a digit). It is only two hex digits, or more accurately one byte. The SBYTE means it is signed using two's complement. movsx is the sign-extended mov operation. Meaning it extends the most significant bit to fill all of the bits in the register that aren't taken up with the initial value

var1 points to -4 (and if you add some offsets, you can point to other bytes but that's besides the point.)

var1 = fc h

edx is an extended register meaning it's 32 bits or four bytes or eight hex chars: ???????? h (we don't know edx's value)

mov edx,var1 would not work because their sizes don't match( 8 bits != 32 bits)

so movsx is used

movsx edx,var1 ; edx = ??????fc h

But movsx also has the additional behavior that it extends the sign bit (the highest bit of var1, which is 1) across the rest of the register.

So it actually looks like this:

movsx edx,var1 ; edx = fffffffc h

and so even though edx is a 32 bit two's complement number, edx still = -4 because of the padding.

entry.title: advanced anaconda
entry.msg:
"The MOVSX instruction (move with sign-extend) copies the contents of a source operand into a destination operand and sign-extends the value to 16 or 32 bits. "

-4 is SBYTE, so it's a one-byte value fch, or 11111100.

The destination register edx is of length 8 bytes. 

So the MOVSX instruction extends the sign bit of fch, which is 1 to fit the gap on the left. Therefore, you get 1s before 11111100 to make it 32 bits. So you end up with fffffffch in hexadecimal.

entry.title: relieved quail
entry.msg:
h

Does Anyone know what the "h" represents for number 4?

entry.title: conceptual catfish
entry.msg: I believe it refers to the values being hexadecimal values. Any variable followed by an h is a hexadecimal value.

entry.title: relaxed python
entry.msg:
The h represent for the hexadecimal, which would usually be used in the .data type. 

For example: 

.data

type1 DWORD 12345678h

entry.title: surviving takin
entry.msg:
It's a suffix identifier that differentiates between decimal and hexadecimal.

.code
.data
   byte_one SBYTE 11
   byte_two SBYTE 11h
   mov eax, byte_one 
   mov ebx, byte_two 
Output:
EAX: 10   EBX: 17

entry.title: agricultural ant
entry.msg: it means that the number you are looking at is hexadecimal. If it were a b then it would be binary, etc
